options.text: It was unaffected, continuing to produce blood cells normally.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What did the author learn about the divide between the sick and the well?

options.label: A
options.text: They learned that it's a clear and distinct line that separates the two.

options.label: B
options.text: They learned that the divide is porous and that many people will travel back and forth between the two.

options.label: C
options.text: They learned that the sick are always weaker and more vulnerable than the well.

options.label: D
options.text: They learned that the well are always stronger and more capable than the sick.

multiple-choice.question: What did the author realize about their own healing process?

options.label: A
options.text: They realized they had to focus on their physical health and ignore their emotional pain.

options.label: B
options.text: They realized they had to stop seeing their health as binary and start accepting their limitations.

options.label: C
options.text: They realized they had to keep pushing themselves to achieve their goals.

options.label: D
options.text: They realized they had to find ways to live in the in-between place and manage their body and mind.

multiple-choice.question: What did the author say was the trick to feeling better and truly being well?

options.label: A
options.text: They said it was to strive for a perfect state of wellness.

options.label: B
options.text: They said it was to stop seeing their health as binary and start accepting their limitations.

options.label: C
options.text: They said it was to find ways to live in the in-between place and manage their body and mind.

options.label: D
options.text: They said it was to quit living in a state of constant dissatisfaction until they reached a perfect state of wellness.
